weather_report:
Perth leans into late afternoon with a sky stippled by passing cloud, the sun slipping through in warm, softened flashes. It feels bright without glare, the kind of light that flatters streets and trees, and though the day’s bite has eased, the UV can still nibble a little before dusk, so a hat or a dab of sunscreen won’t go astray. Toward evening the patches gather into broader veils, trimming the shine and lending the horizon a gentle, silvery hush. The air looks clean, edges still crisp, then more watercolor as twilight takes over.

It’s a day for light layers: short sleeves now, something easy to pull on later when the air cools. If you’re out, sunglasses until the sun dips; after that, you’ll want comfort more than armor. Mundane pleasures suit the mood—an unhurried walk to post a letter, a lap around the block with the dog, watering the herbs, or a quick ride to pick up that missing ingredient. Windows cracked open, a simple dinner on the stove, and a glance toward a muted sunset that may glow through the gaps.
